number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Don't look at my steam play time, I've been playing since Open Beta 2, and I have to say, no MMO comes close to touching this one!As a veteran WoW player who was part of many world and server firsts, the whole cookie cutter spec got stale, as did paying a monthly fee. While I had to pay a fee each month to play this, it was soon found that there are hundreds of talent tree combinations that are all viable for everything! It's amazing, and it really shows how much care Trion put into this game. I specialized and generalized and each had its merits in the grand scale of the game.The world is also huge. There is never downtime, unless you make downtime by going into a city and standing there. I was questing once when I was a low level and a rift opened  right above me. As I was fighting for my life, another rift opened up a few meters away. Then, both rift's creatures started fighting eachother, it was amazing how alive the world feels! Finally, the community is amazing. People who are jerks or trolls get black listed by everybody, so they can no longer progress. This means that people don't do those things and everyone is super helpful. Even endgame grindy quests are made fun and easy with good partners. Basically, if you like WoW, or if you want to try a new MMO, play Rift. With the money you save from subscription fees, you can put it to supporting Trion through their store, and the community and world will ensure that you have a good time.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Streamlined and cheaper version of WoW with extremely boring world and lore. Apart from the auction house being locked behind a pay wall (which really hurts player economy) there really isn't bad P2W content and most of the stuff you can buy with real money is just optional cosmetic trash or cuts down the time needed to level up. It feels like the game is still designed with free players in mind first since buying those boosters would just quickly overlevel you out of questing and dungeon areas.The rift opening and other overworld raiding events are fun, bringing random players together and being able to mix different talent trees to make your own class is pretty neat in my opinion. Worth a try if you're looking for a new MMORPG without the risk of shelling money first.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
Product received for free
												Note: My hours played are misleading. I've played this on and off since its release on Steam, and this review is based on my most recent experience with the game.Rift is a moderately fun - if generic - WoW-style MMO. The combat is solid, there are plenty of quests to do, and the world is fun enough to explore. But what killed it for me is the sheer volume of micro-transactions. I've never played a game so overflowing with them. I'm not exaggerating when I say that nearly every inch of the interface has an obnoxious premium currency symbol on it telling you that you could pay real money to unlock something. It even worms its way into questing - during the handful of hours I played my new character, I looted no less than 30 lockboxes from monsters that required keys bought with real money to open, and every single quest hand-in screen showed me I could be getting more money and XP if I was a subscriber. No matter how enjoyable its gameplay might be, I just can't recommend such a money hungry game to anyone. It's desperate to the point of being gross.

content:

												Before anyone tell me I don't know what I'm doing, I spent a few hours looking through website forums trying to understand what was going on because the game would not launch. I even deleted and reinstalled 2 additional times but the game would never start. My computer is more than able to handle it (Can run Tomb Raider at Ultimate settings).I kept getting errors on startup telling me that I needed to update, then when i did run the update it downloaded about 150 mb of info and then said it couldn't apply the update successfully and I needed to redownload the entire game again.I really wanted to play, but after 12 hours of downloading it 3 times and reading tons of forum posts I'm giving up. No game should be this ridiculous to install, especially when it has been out for years.

												This game is truly amazing, takes a while to get into the good♥♥♥♥♥♥in the game. When you get out of one of the 2 faction spawns (Guardians or Defiants). This game INCOURAGES exploring the world, they have fetch quests but its not as bad as some other MMORPGS. They give you the quest, you finish it and go to a different person, some long distances some small. The skill tree is really good, could use a bit more in my oppinion but decent. The community is very friendly, invite people to guilds so they can help them if they have questions or even be very kind and give you a free mount or such. I was lvl 20-25 (cant remember) but you get a 60% speed increase when on the mount, people in my guild were talking about that mount which is 25plat which is quite a bit for a lvl 20-25 and i said that its very hard to get one, one of the guildies/guild member brought me that mount to be very very kind and they were a high ranking player. PVP is truly amazing and takes alot of skill and time, the most annoying thing in pvp for me is getting your faction swapped to the enemy team to balance it out which is a good thing but you want to be with your faction, either way its fun. The game has a wardrobe feature meaning if you have a piece of armor or something you can but it in your wardrobe slot for example, Helm and it goes into your wardrobe slot and it gives the look but not the stats. Microtransactions are okay... i guess, you dont HAVE to buy them for the game to be good, they are just things like if you play a mage you get 3 BASE things to choose from, example stormcaller, warlock ect and the Microtransactions give you a couple of new ones that dont make a HUGE difference. The Map is ♥♥♥♥ING HUGE and each zone like Gloamwood, Silverwood and every other one has their own secret stash like thing, if you open it you get ramdom armor of your class that rounds down to every 5 LEVELS, if you are lvl 20 you will get a lvl 20 item. If you are lvl17 you will get a lvl 15 item. Puzzles are great, they require teamwork like pressing several buttons that open a globe that your break and has a key in it, then it spawns a chest with a dirty bag, the same thing like the secret stashes like i said previously.I would rate this game 7.5/10 but i do recommend this game if you love MMORPGSCons:The start of the game is very very boring and you need to be about lvl 15 for♥♥♥♥♥♥to kick off.Can be very annoying to get the kind of gear you want but its an MMORPG sooo......Microtransactions are ehhh, would be better without it but.....Wish there was gliders and boats like Archeage but mounts are good enough.Pros:Friendly communityCharacter creation is very very good.Fun game after lvl 15Great PVPWardrobeHuge mapGreat secret treasuresGreat puzzles that require teamwork to complete

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												I enjoyed playing RIFT for a while, but it then I just got sick of it.  I spent a chunk of real life money on bag/bank space and without doing so, the game is quite hard to play.  I didn't feel that I got a return for that investment.  I enjoy exploring and farming.  This game has some nice exploring, with caves that are nice to find and some semi-secret bosses that you can stumble on there.  The dungeons are instance based and I didn't warm to their style.  You can't go in without a party and again, I just didn't see much reward for going there.  It's not that farmable and I didn't really feel crafting with drops gave much reward in game.  My first MMO was Rappelz and until the economy there was tipped too far in favour of cash shop and they got rid of event farming, that was my model for other MMOs.   It seems that there aren't MMOs out there now that will balance their game and the in-game economy to recognise the various player types.  I was a prolific farmer, that spent the occasional bit of money in the cash shop, but prospered through a lot of grinding/farming.  My drops were purchased by others, including people with not as much time or patience, but willing/able to spend a lot of real life cash.  That MMO and it seems most others nowadays don't respect the farming type that feeds the other gamers with items.  In fact, they tend to add a bit of token crafting and fishing to keep people occupied, but the drops from those activities don't have an economic value in game.  It's all about the cash and Rift, with other free to play MMO's is really pay to play.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												Warning: NEVER VERIFY THE GAMEThe Glyph launcher sometimes updates every hour or so and then f's up which can result in having to download big sections of the game again. As a result, these days I never play until the game has fully updated even though the game says you can start to play while it downloads content in the background.Do not trust any forum post or article that suggest you use Steam to verify the game as most files will fail the check and it will try to download almost the entire game again. (Apparently I was trolled by a forum post that suggested I verify after re-installing the game... which caused the whole game to be downloaded by steam again, and then Glyph would dowload the game again after the steam verify. At 20GB per ... that's a lot of download.)As a new player I am of course impressed by the sheer anmount of content in the game. But the P2W and Greed of Trion is evident everywhere. Your bag fills up with items that require paid money to open, which wastes time because you have VERY limited bagspace and so have keep discarding these 'Pay to unlock' loot that you get while fighting.The VERY limited bagspace can of course be unlocked and expanded to 8x more space but the real money you have to pay increases exponentialloy with each slot. The last slot requires the most expensive DLC the game has to offer.The P2W is so strong with this one that one post estimates you have to pay 17x the price of a tripple A game and then put in about 1,500 hours to use it all. If you don't pay up... then you can grind till you die, have your kids grind till they die and maybe your grandkids can equal the powers of the players who are playing today.As a result, I am of course not planning to spend a dime, and as such have no way of ever seeing end game because by the time I get to the current 'free' end-game it will probably have been put behind a paywall. That's right folks... stuff that is 'free' right now won't be free in the future.... eg: earrings, auction house, Planar etc. But fear not! Even though the free content is now behind a paywall, you can aim for the new free stuff we have that you can get to with several thousand hours of grinding. But you better hurry up... because in a few thousand hours we might just paywall it because of all the players complaining about how long it takes to get there!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												Rift hit the massively multiplayer online scene a few years ago and since it has become one of the largest and most popular games of the genre. Rift is a free, micro-transaction based game set in a high fantasy world. Rift established a few boundaries that other massively multiplayer online games have done well to copy. Some of the most fundamental things that Rift did different – and did right include a free to play structure, the limiting of abilities to a more refined, limited selection and also the addition of an interactive and evolving game-world. These things have established Rift as a pathfinder in the market and make it a sturdy title to contend with.Though originally for a foreign audience, Rift was repackaged for westerners due to demand. The game allows for extensive customization of your avatar as well as plenty of micro-transactions which are purely for aesthetic appeal. This becomes one of the biggest gripes most gamers tend to have, that distinction must be “bought.” Even though by no means does the game require you to purchase anything to play, the cash store and micro-transactions are present to make the game profitable. People complain that micro-transactions destroy the game and make you spend excessive amounts of money on the game – but let's take a step back and examine the situation. Micro-transactions ensure that you only pay for content you're going to use, or at least want and generally a few little purchases dwarfs in comparison to shelling out the full retail price for the game package and a monthly subscription cost. Micro-transactions are good for players and game producers alike.Another are that Rift excels in is the open world environment which invites you to explore and experiment. As the name of the game implies, rifts to other dimensions can be opened in the world – sometimes willingly sometimes spontaneously. Generally rifts are conquered by players to gain rewards, but sometimes if left to its own devices a rift might grow and begin to call in reinforcement troops which will assault towns, players and other rifts. This dynamic creates a totally different feel to the game, because normally titles in this genre have a rule of thumb that the world itself is pretty unchangeable by the players. Though you're not exactly reshaping the world with developer's tools, being able to open and close rifts gives you a sense of mastery of environment not seen elsewhere.Another concept adopted and brought forward by Rift is the reduction of abilities and the simplification of controls. Recently, even big names such as World of Warcraft have taken steps to remove abilities and simplify gameplay. If anyone has ever compared the difference between abilities in older massively multiplayer online games and newer titles, one notices that newer titles only offer a limited selection of active abilities which can be changed but never giving the player an excess of options. For the casual player your head literally could spin trying to remember all of the abilities, commands, keybinds and micros found in more classic massively multiplayer online titles. Streamlined abilities are what make this game great and easy to pick up and play by even casual gamers.The graphics are crisp and inspiring, definitely with the quality level expected for a game of modern times. Of course being on a personal computer engine, largely the graphics will depend on your settings but with maxed out specifications the game itself is stunning. Even on lower settings, the quality and attention to detail brought to the plate are sure to impress. Textures aren't everything though, animations are smooth, monsters are imaginative yet still fitting and the scenery and terrain are world class. Similar detail is also seen in the audio of the game, going into great detail to make sure ever effect has the right sound and that the melodies are peppered with dramatic but suitable overtures serving to further immerse one into the also visually stunning environment.Sometimes the worlds of online multiplayer gaming can be threatening or maybe just a little intimidating. For the casual console gamer of the past, when looking at a massively multiplayer online game one is probably reminded of a dungeons and dragons setup. Without sacrificing depth and the details many online gamers do like, Rift gives casual players an opportunity to enjoy the genre as well. Because it does not require any purchases, its easy for anyone to gain access to the game and try it out. Newer players will be drawn in by the content and ease of play the streamlined abilities offer. Though it is a step into definite nerddom I definitely recommend Rift to anyone interested. It's free after all, give it a try! If you would like a chance to play for free, be sure to check it out!http://www.playerschoicereview.com/2015/03/players-choice-review-rift.html

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												Rift is a MMORPG (Massive multiplayer online role playing game) with a large game lore, themed in an epic medieval fantasy world.Pros:- There is a lot to do in the game, being it discovering the ever-growing world, crafting for your trade-skills (building equipment or enhancements for your own use, for your friends, guild or anyone in the world), finding dungeons and finishing quests, or simply completing daily or weekly quests in raids.- You can customize your character in a moderate way, but you can unlock a large amount of armors, weapons and mounts to customize your outer appearance.- You can have your own dimensión in which you can place a ot of things, any way you want, in any size you want. Despite there is a limited (but very large) collectión of items you may place in there, your imagination is the limit.- Did I say that there is always something to do? Add to the above constant invasions from other planes, leaded by large bosses who will need a lot of people to take down.- There is a lot of room for addons and macros that you can customize to simplify battles and  other ingame intercations.Cons:- The game is very intensive on system requirements for players who want to see the beauty of the world.- The game is very expensive if you want a little bonus for your character (being it a slightly faster mount for patreons, extra slots for bags or unlocking gear slots), and has the weird statement of blocking basic interactions (you must do an initial payment to use auction houses, the regular method of player trading) instead of awarding in a better way the players who buy stuff from the game (I've bought a few stuff out of need, but the reward felt quite expensive).- Based on the above, if you are not willing to pay the varied prices for some little benefit, the game might look like you can't reach the end-game content because you might be under geared (e.g.: can't do enough damage to a boss because you lack "firepower"), and sometimes it will look like a lot of work (because you can get game credits from other players, but they are even more expensive).Do I recommend the game? I DO!Despite all the work you may need to get stuff in the game, the game is really fun to play. The player comunity is growing, which makes every event more fun... because aside the quests and the invasions, there are seasonal events and many other things to do. My advice? Give it a try if you like fantasy games. We might end fighting a massive boss together (and I mean massive... check youtube if you do not believe me) ;).

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												I enjoyed playing RIFT for a while, but it then I just got sick of it.  I spent a chunk of real life money on bag/bank space and without doing so, the game is quite hard to play.  I didn't feel that I got a return for that investment.  I enjoy exploring and farming.  This game has some nice exploring, with caves that are nice to find and some semi-secret bosses that you can stumble on there.  The dungeons are instance based and I didn't warm to their style.  You can't go in without a party and again, I just didn't see much reward for going there.  It's not that farmable and I didn't really feel crafting with drops gave much reward in game.  My first MMO was Rappelz and until the economy there was tipped too far in favour of cash shop and they got rid of event farming, that was my model for other MMOs.   It seems that there aren't MMOs out there now that will balance their game and the in-game economy to recognise the various player types.  I was a prolific farmer, that spent the occasional bit of money in the cash shop, but prospered through a lot of grinding/farming.  My drops were purchased by others, including people with not as much time or patience, but willing/able to spend a lot of real life cash.  That MMO and it seems most others nowadays don't respect the farming type that feeds the other gamers with items.  In fact, they tend to add a bit of token crafting and fishing to keep people occupied, but the drops from those activities don't have an economic value in game.  It's all about the cash and Rift, with other free to play MMO's is really pay to play.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												If you like MMOs and have never played Rift (or stopped playing a long time ago), you should definitely give it a try. Leveling is actually fun and you have different options to chose from: you can level the traditional way - by questing solo, you can level only through PvP, or if you like group play and want to level as a tank or healer, you can just hop into a dungeon or instant adventure (which puts you in a random raid that does scaled quest chains in one of the zones).The biggest issue when you're starting out are the graphics and the slightly outdated feel of the game, but I found that I got used to it quickly.For a free game, Rift is top-notch and certainly worth trying out for everyone but the biggest MMO haters.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												ReviewStarted this good ol game up again 171 hours, got sucked in again, i really like it, a lot the npc and monsters could use some life, but most MMO's are like that. Yes there is a major cash shop, but you get free stuff and a lot can be bought through the Auction House, trading, grinding, getting a job and supporting a free game by buying a little here and there, basicly i never shy away from buying bag/bank space, mounts and pets, and skins, the rest never cared for.Max level is 29 Dwarven Warrior Tank, also have a 20 something Hunter type and a few alts, fun game would keep playing it, games like this to me would be Lord of the Rings online, Dungeon & Dragons online, World of Warcraft.Crafting, Questing, Farming, and Grinding it has it all, what it has that really keeps me are Events, and i don't mean server events, the Rifts, i like how they appear, kept me going.Only two Character slots per shard for free, i am sure you can buy more, Really good Tutoria and the leveling is neat the screen flashes.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Ok,so I had to rewrite the review as i got more hours in this amazing game.Enjoy the following review.So,to get started,this is an amazing MMORPG game,all the classic things you will find in MMORPG's;mounts,pets,classes.. etc.But it also offers an innovative take on an MMORPG,such as; random rifts erupting everywhere,incredible and huge zone events,incredibly large and detailed lore,and the ability to make your own DIMENSION,yes an entire dimension for yourself...Now,lets talk about these things: Mounts:There's a huge amount of mounts,ranging from a 60% speed boost,to a 100% speed boost.They all look incredible and are available already at lvl 15(approx. 30-35 hours).Pets:There are 2 types of pets: companion and combat.Companion pets can be bought with in-game coins later on.Combat pets are the pets that you can summon with your class.(some classes summon elementals,some summon animals...)Classes:There are 4 classes:Rogue,Cleric,Mage and Warrior.each class has about 6-8 "souls".These souls are an incredibly detailed way of making your own class and playstyle.They are kind of a...subclass.Example: A Rogue has these(and more souls): Saboteur,Ranger,Riftwalker,Bladedancer,Bard etc.Rifts:Rifts are holes in dimensions through which monsters from diffrent plains of existence come to invade Telara(more info in the lore).They are tiny events,which yield nice rewards in the end.Zone events:These dont occur so often,possibly once in about 3-4 hours,they are mostly "invasions".When rifts stay opened for too long,invasions of monsters attack the nearby places,if they are not stopped in time,a zone event will occur,leading in an all out war for 30 minutes,with an enormous boss in the end,and with massive rewards.Make your dimension:Now this is quite unusual.You can make your dimension(aka your "home") anyway you want it to be,you will learn how somewhere around lvl 10(approx 10-15 hours of gameplay).You can place items in there,place statues,buildings and many more.Review in short(for people who dont like to read huge texts):Rift is a classical,yet an innovative game,offering many challenges.I suggest looking up some tutorials before you play it,as it can be quite complicated for a new player.Rift offers non-stop events and action,of course,if you get tired of the action,you can take a rest at your faction's capital or your dimension.You can also invite your friends to hang out in your dimension as well.All in all:Rift is a MMORPG packed with Dungeons,Rifts,Raids and Zone Events.Innovative,yet classical.If you liked this game try out:DefianceThats it,hope you enjoy the game :D

												Pretty cool MMO. A little strange to get into at first but once you've settled in the game becomes quite fun. Very WoW-ish in the mechanics and HUD setup, but I assume most MMO's are like that in a way. The music is a little drab, but I'm not going to expect a massive budget on a FTP game. The controls are a bit iffy, but all is good through changing settings and all that. The world looks really vast and I expect to spend quite a fair amount of time playing this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												A truly amazing experience. This game showed me how good a free to play game can get and how much you can do without paying a dime. The class system was super fun for me because I would always try out crazy combos just to see what I could come up with and how it would do against other players in World PvP. The graphics of this game are something else, they are absolutely fantastic and you truly feel immersed in the epic fantasy world of Telara. The Rifts bring random players together of both factions to take down a common enemy and then after the Rift closes everyone collects rewards and it feels awesome knowing you took down a public event with a large group of people. The zone events are just as awesome and require the whole zone to contribute to taking down a massive boss. I would highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a free to play game to spend some time on, maybe you'll get hooked the way I did.

												Let it be known, that I've actually played this quite a lot on the individual client as well (which if you can go without Steam, is probably the simpler choice). See, I only played through the game with a single character, and I reached around level 50 (I believe there are 60 or 70?) without spending any money, except for maybe an outfit or two for a character.In my opinion, this game is how Free to Play should be done, it's very enjoyable, and while you may not b e able to tackle every single dungeon in the game without paying some money, or grinding, it's still a wonderful time. I got over 250 hours out of a game I didn't pay a dime for, and that's more than I've gotten out of most games!

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												GOODReally great game if you like online mmo style, "run round doing quests killing NPCs" kind of game, leveling up and deveoping your character. BADI don't like the auction system. You cannot just join and use it to sell items you crafted etc, it seems you need "Loyalty" whatever that is... This is the one thing I would like to see changed. Otherwise its a good way to kill time.OVERALLGame is playable and has room for improvement, not bad for a free game.  I give it a 7/10 and would encourage others to play.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												1. Game is extremely similar to World of Warcraft. This is a pro and a con. It's a pro because World of Warcraft is awesome, who wouldn't want to play a similar game. It's also a con as some players are looking for something new. That being said let's cover some points that newer players want to hear. 2. You can play this game for months and still have things left to do. There are thousands of quests and a healthy playerbase.3. Combat system is nothing new for MMOs and will grow stale quickly for veterans. 4. game is advertised as free. is it? NO! if you've ever played tf2 when it went f2p you'll understand this. in rift as a free player you get a couple bag slots, a couple character slots and a couple other restrictions such as not being able to make auctions in the auction house until you spend 5 bucks of real money to make it otherwise. there is no way to get bag slots besides real money or getting to max level and selling a lot of harvested materials for REX (real currency sold by players).technically you can say this game is "free" however free in this case would be sadly comparable to slavery as you must act as a slave in order to obtain that amount of currency. this could take you weeks of gameplay which will not be enjoyable.5. the dungeons are fantastic. they are generic at first but eventually you will have a reasonably challenging time. it's an enjoyable way to level up if you are playing as a tank/healer.6. the questing SUCKS. It's the most grinding in an MMO i've ever seen. we're talking 50+ quests to get up 1 level at level 40+ (level cap is 60 holy hell)in conclusion, do i reccomend this game? sort of. i play with my brother in dungeons etc but that's about it. the novely died off fast. for new mmo players this game may be completely overwhelming and without a friend who knows his way around you won't get far fast.for new mmo players, stay away from this game unless you have friends who also play.for people who left wow because it cost too much, here's a cheap alternatiive.

												Let it be known, that I've actually played this quite a lot on the individual client as well (which if you can go without Steam, is probably the simpler choice). See, I only played through the game with a single character, and I reached around level 50 (I believe there are 60 or 70?) without spending any money, except for maybe an outfit or two for a character.In my opinion, this game is how Free to Play should be done, it's very enjoyable, and while you may not b e able to tackle every single dungeon in the game without paying some money, or grinding, it's still a wonderful time. I got over 250 hours out of a game I didn't pay a dime for, and that's more than I've gotten out of most games!

content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												Edit: If you like PvP, and want to choose map/mode, this game might not be for you, if you plan on playing it for free. I myself don't really like PvP, so I'm giving it a positive review.I've been trying out a lot of MMOs, but I keep falling back to this one.For being a F2P game it's really good, and has lots to offer. There are no "pay to win" options, except being able to buy out more slots for proffesions (which I love, since then I can be more creative with my Dimensions), and cosmetic stuff/nice looking mounts.This game doesn't push you to pay for gems, but instead they reward you with great gifts if you do :) And alot of the stuff you can buy can also be bought with in-game cash, but you might have to grind some for it :) There are also a way to get gems with in-game cash, you just need to buy it from other players :) This also will require a lot of grinding, though.There aren't many races on each alliance, but the 4 classes in the game can be built almost however you like it, especially if you buy the 2 soul-packs.This game isn't just good with the gameplay, it looks good as well. The gameplay is really similar to World of Warcraft, but Rift has a better look and is F2P. So for those who are looking for a F2P game similar to WoW, this might be your free WoW-clone :) Since it's free, it's worth to at least try once :p9/10 from me!

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												I've played this game off and on since launch. I have to say is this: The game is great. They consistently add large amounts of content. This is due to the money they are making off of the FTP you all seem to hate. The content flow is greater, larger and more consistent than the sub base. Every time I come back, plenty new to discover. If you're looking for a free to play MMO, there is no questions this is probably the best. By free to play, I mean completely free to start playing. Not buy once, continue playing, puchasing items here and there. Here, you download, play for free, entire game if you want, and put some money in it if you want as well. You can't get everything for free? Get over it. It's a great game. Great content. Solid.I hope it makes enough money to justify a Rift 2, one that isn't over shadowed by a still going strong WoW. When this game was released it was called a WoW clone. As was every other MMO during that time. Guild wars 2 was the only one that managed to drift away, but took a long time to become what it is now. As did Rift. As did WoW.And this is free. Being compared to those games. Skip the reviews. Play it, or don't. Just don't waste your time reading peoples reviews that complain a massive MMORPG, isn't 150% free. Go play SWTOR. Check out those FtP restrictions. Or any other Ftp MMO...

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												At first I thought it was just another WoW clone. On the surface that is very much what it looks like. In fact its one of the most WoW lookin WoW clones I've ever played. In a way though thats good. Seasoned WoW players can jump right in. For me though the sheer amount of WoW clones is what essentially made me give up on the MMO scene for a long time. I found most MMORPG's lately are just very stale and repetitive with too much grinding for not enough reward However as you play the game more you learn about the rift invasions, soul swapping and many other features that just bring a whole new depth into the game. You can completely customise your characters by combining 3 different classes together. I recently looted some gear that was recommended for a Cleric Rogue Warrior. That pretty much says it all as far as I'm concerned. Not to mention that theres none of this "Reach level X and pay a ridiculous amount of (game currency) to learn how to ride a boring slow horse". When I was level 15 (and essentially still learning how to play the game) and on my way to buy my first, reasonably priced, mount I looted a very cool collectable Hellbug mount from a standard Rift event, that starts off at the slowest mounts speed but will increase speed to match my fastest mount when I get one. I thought this was a very nice touch.From my experience so far it pretty much cuts all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that you encounter in most other MMO's that make them such  awful grinds and keeps you entertained and engaged the whole time. Highly recommended to any fans of MMORPGs

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This is probably my favorite MMORPG. I've only played a few, counting this one. And so far, this one has not failed to impress. Even on the lowered graphics I'm forced to play on, due to my laptop, the game still looks amazing. The gameplay, since I'm used to its controls, is intense but not overwhelming. A lot of the MMORPG elements found in similar games by other companies are still present, but Glyph really outdid themselves in Rift. The socia lsystem is very neat and organized, and gameplay is nice, and I just think this is a fantastic game comepletely. The only thing I think Glyph should add is a chat system. That would really immerse the players even more. But then again, this is just my opinion. I give it 8.5 Platinum/10 Platinum. I recommend this game to anyone who likes MMORPG's that are not too complex.

content:
Posted: April 3
												As a former World of Warcraft player, I have to say that I enjoy the world of RIFT much better. Aside from the missions you accumulate throughout the game, you get to open and seal Rifts and gain notoriety and other goodies. The story line is interesting and is, so far, fun to live out. You can collect items that offer side missions which garner coins, notoriety and other rewards. The Ascended Carnival is going on at the moment and it also offers new and interesting games and items. Overall, I would give this game a solid 4 1/2 stars out of 5. The only things I don't like are the need to keep purchasing tokens with real money with no way to earn any in-game and the fact that there are only 6 different character types. I'd like to have more character types to choose from, but other than those 2 minor issued, it's an all around grat game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5
												I always come back and try Rift when a new major update drops just to see what's changed since the first release. Here's my thoughts having played Storm Legion and Nightmare Tide a fair bit (without Starfall Prophecy):The game is absolutely beautiful and much of the content is very creative and isn't "grindy" like Aion (flashbacks) or... whatever Tera is. The class system is much like Guild Wars except there's not really a dominant meta because every class (now) can do everything (after you pass a pay wall). The levelling is quite fast now to get you into "relevant territory" which, for me, is a shame. D&DO's,  WoW's, and EQ2's vanilla progressions were tight because you had to *work* to get to end game and you felt a sense of satisfaction when you accomplished it.That all being said, RIFT is different now. The LFR and Dungeon system that matches you with people and funnels you around Telara to power-level is... interesting. MMOs have become more bite-sized and if you like that, you might like RIFT. Is it better than, say, Legion? Probably not. The aestethics are there, but the polish and weight to your play isn't.Overall, I'd recommend it with the caveat that it's because it's better than most MMORPGs out there. It's not the best but it's "free".

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												TL;DR, Don't waste your time.I waited for this to download. I waited for Glyph to install. I waited for the e-mail from Glyph that told me I had to do it because I was using a different computer. I waited for Glyph to update. I waited for Glyph to tell me the current version of my game needed to be completely re-installed. I waited for it to install it all again. I waited and waited, all so I could play this game and you know what? I have no FREAKIN' idea why I did!I got to the fabled Customization menu. I figured since so many people were saying such great and grand things about it that I'd love it to death. You see I have this problem with loving to customize my characters too much that I spend hours in it. After picking a side and a character type I finally saw the options it gave. Really? That's it? I've seen better customization in Vindictus or APB. It's literally ever so slightly better than SWTOR's customization but it leaves a lot of room for improvement. Oh, wait, you have to buy those improvements... with real money. Great. So I get one set of options and everything else possible is something I have to buy. Nothing I haven't seen before. So I ignored it.My character looked about as generic as a Skyrim character by the end of it. And you know what else? It looked worse In-game than it did in the character creation screen. I figured it was my settings. I noticed that it was set to Custom and that everything looked terrible. I did what any smart gamer would do and put it to Ultra. It looked the exact freakin' same. I put it to Custom and maxed out everything slowly, checking for differences in between. No changes that greatly improved the game's look. Wow, so everything looks like a dated 2000's MMO game. Awesome! -_-So my character's head looked well modeled but the body didn't. I could clearly see a low texture just under the neck line as everything there looked like pixels. Burry, crappy, pixels. This was all with everything on Maximum settings. Sure, the hair looked nice and shinny and never changed but my character's arms looked off, either too long or too pixeled. I blamed the textures.I figured, maybe the gameplay is better than it looks since the menu selecting my class type looked very promising. HA! Big fat nothing there. It's basically a mish-mash of talents used to create a supposed new class. I ended up getting two skills that are almost 100% exactly the same. The "build guide" used for the Tanky Tank just placed points into both Tanking trees and gave whatever double ups there were. The talents in general are either meh or interesting but there just so damn many of them. The trees also go in two directions. I hadn't seen split points since Titan Quest and at least there it did it right. Alright, so were the skills at least good? Nope. Basically exactly the same as WoW with possibly better looking icons and Action Bar animations. The XP bar looked great but leveling up was pretty lackluster.So, I played the damn game. I accepted quests and did as they asked. Normal stupid fetch this, or wack that 4 times. None of them were interesting or challenging. I continued, I used my skills like they were intended but I must be too low a level to feel the real greatness of the game because after leveling a few times on the most boring enemies period, It was just tiresome. Enemies that did attack you, didn't pose an actual threat. Enemies you attacked, barely could defend themselves. I stopped attacking to see if one could kill me and it took so long just to get me CLOSE to half health that I killed it. The combat never improved enough to stop me from being bored of it as a whole. My skills weren't interesting to use nor were they fun.The animations looked like a good start but the actual skills were just copy-pastes. The skill effects were as you expected up until the fact that the Tank is basically playing as a Rogue. Instead of Combo Points I have... Attack Points. Like WoW, I get the little icon and improve damage.The areas looked less fantasy like and more generic MMO trying its hardest to be realistic looking. For me, it looked bland, boring and useless. Nothing was unique about it. Nothing I haven't seen a million times in lesser games already.I couldn't get past how worse than WoW it looked and felt. For a WoW clone you'd think they'd get this down.Anyway, I've moaned enough about this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												This game is only ok. It is a run-of-the-mill MMORPG and adds nothing new to the genre. The combat model is old news and boring. The maps are particularly bad when you get into a dungeon. The world map shows the suface not the dungeon; and the mini-map is too small to see the entire dungeon. One of the more troubling aspects of the game is the use of quests triggering one-way portals to areas that are above your level. They should at least give you the chance to refuse portal. Then you could research the quest to determine if you want to do it. As it is you get locked into an area where you can't get out without completing every branch of the quests. If you get stuck and can't get help your best bet is to start a new character. Lots of people have said how helpful everyone is and it is no different from any other MMORPG. I have a ticket open for 24 hours with no response. I asked for help in-game and could not find any players willing to help. If you are considering playing this, don't buy any of the content or subscribe to it until you have played it for several days.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												At first I thought it was just another WoW clone. On the surface that is very much what it looks like. In fact its one of the most WoW lookin WoW clones I've ever played. In a way though thats good. Seasoned WoW players can jump right in. For me though the sheer amount of WoW clones is what essentially made me give up on the MMO scene for a long time. I found most MMORPG's lately are just very stale and repetitive with too much grinding for not enough reward However as you play the game more you learn about the rift invasions, soul swapping and many other features that just bring a whole new depth into the game. You can completely customise your characters by combining 3 different classes together. I recently looted some gear that was recommended for a Cleric Rogue Warrior. That pretty much says it all as far as I'm concerned. Not to mention that theres none of this "Reach level X and pay a ridiculous amount of (game currency) to learn how to ride a boring slow horse". When I was level 15 (and essentially still learning how to play the game) and on my way to buy my first, reasonably priced, mount I looted a very cool collectable Hellbug mount from a standard Rift event, that starts off at the slowest mounts speed but will increase speed to match my fastest mount when I get one. I thought this was a very nice touch.From my experience so far it pretty much cuts all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that you encounter in most other MMO's that make them such  awful grinds and keeps you entertained and engaged the whole time. Highly recommended to any fans of MMORPGs

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												If you're looking for an MMO (why would you do this?), you could do a hell of a lot worse. Trion knows what they're doing w/r/t game balance, and the flexibility of the soul system gives you a lot of versatility while soloing and in dungeons -- every class is capable of damage-dealing and at least one other role (like tanking or healing), and you can swap roles at any time when you're not in combat. Add in a robust player housing system with dimensions and a bunch of ridiculously awesome, though not particularly necessary, IRL moneysinks and you've got yourself a pretty fun MMO. Trion releases new content at a good clip, too!

Play it, or don't. Just don't waste your time reading peoples reviews that complain a massive MMORPG, isn't 150% free. Go play SWTOR. Check out those FtP restrictions. Or any other Ftp MMO...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												Alright. This will probably be lengthy.My perspective on the game: I was once a top raider in the game. I have also put hundreds of hours into the game as a casual. The 728 hours that steam has me, is only when I played the game through steam. I have over 1,000 easy. I started playing at the start of Storm Legion, RIFT's 2nd expansion. So that's a bit about me.Game's content: Readily avaiable to you is 3 full expansions worth of content. If you want to play the game solo, you have 3 expansions of achievements, shinies, and whatever else you could want. You will have to drop some cash if you want access to the auction house, or you can save up plat to get it for free by getting a rex from another player in game. Beyond that, there are old world dungeon queues that will take around an hour or longer to pop. You can keep playing the game while you wait for the queue to pop, as in you can continue questing. Due to DPS/health changes that happened during RIFT's 3rd expansion, these dungeons have become very easy. Basically you can level on your own until about lvl 60 before you even see more than 2 or 3 other people in the game. Once you hit the 60-65 zones you might see 4-5 people every couple hours. At end game, which is were most players are, you will  be at the lull while players are waiting for the new expansion. It's a good time to join RIFT because the new level cap means the new BIS gear is going to be available in the 2 new dungeons. how the loot drops will work to cover 5 classes in 2 dungeons is beyond me, but we'll see.Instant Adventures: *INTREPID* For some reason this is one of the games biggest selling points. For reasons beyond me, people actually do this. Basically it takes you through the end game raids in more fun enviroment. The maps are huge and look amazing, but what you actually do is very quest grindy. Kill these, click those, and then finally you do a boss with some basic mechanics that could kill a whole bunch of you. Team work within your group is required. *OTHER THAN INTREPID* Well, that is based in the open world and you will be running around basically questing.PVP: Not so good. The skill cap is pretty low. As in you won't be able to 1 vs 3... and they'd have to be pretty bad for you to 1 vs 2. That would make you feel okay, but this is a game where people make 1 or 2 button macros and ignore the rest of their abilities. If you take the time and research your class and actually read your soul tree, you'll do above average in pvp, but it isn't really what you want to play this game for.Raiding: Not really competitive at the moment. Mostly casual players going through the raids at a steady pace. Once a guild or 2 clears content at a difficult setting, the raid is nerfed to allow more players to clear content, and then nerfed again and again until the most casual players can clear the content. That's not a bad thing. They do look stunning though. And they fit the lore very well. You can go back and solo some of the vanilla raids, and they just look so cool. Hedges constantly moving around like a maze. It really is fun to go into them.The Developers: This topic could be long, but I'll just keep it short. This would be the only valid reason to not play this game. Just check out the MMORift reddit page to see a couple area's where the dev team has screwed the player base.Cash shop: It isn't as bad as most players think. It's worth mentioning that 2 expacs came out before RIFT went F2P. It's very noticeable. You will hit a paywall with the newest expansion to arrive in November, and only slight pay walls before that. Everything up to this point is attainable without spending cash. It helps to reduce time, but isn't required what-so-ever. With the latest expansion you simply pay for it, no choice in skipping time, it's just a hard paywall. I am guessing this will be RIFT's last expansion, so DO NOT RUSH! If there's an option to grind, just take your time and do it. It will be a slow moving game from here on out.Why am I saying you should play it? The timing is great. You can drop $40 on the game and play the newest expansion in a game that is about to turn into a very filtered community. As in the people that you log on and play with everyday are going to be Really good people. They might not be amazing at the game, but they will make you laugh and you will have fun with them. You will slowly progress through content, probably not by choice, but that will be how the pacing will work. RIFT is going to go into a low life-support mode after the expansion and that can be a very good thing for a long term player. You will have a boat load of time to catch up if they ever do release new content, and you will enjoy the time with some of the best players the MMO community has left to offer. As long as the devs leave you alone, play the hell out of this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												TL;DR, Don't waste your time.I waited for this to download. I waited for Glyph to install. I waited for the e-mail from Glyph that told me I had to do it because I was using a different computer. I waited for Glyph to update. I waited for Glyph to tell me the current version of my game needed to be completely re-installed. I waited for it to install it all again. I waited and waited, all so I could play this game and you know what? I have no FREAKIN' idea why I did!I got to the fabled Customization menu. I figured since so many people were saying such great and grand things about it that I'd love it to death. You see I have this problem with loving to customize my characters too much that I spend hours in it. After picking a side and a character type I finally saw the options it gave. Really? That's it? I've seen better customization in Vindictus or APB. It's literally ever so slightly better than SWTOR's customization but it leaves a lot of room for improvement. Oh, wait, you have to buy those improvements... with real money. Great. So I get one set of options and everything else possible is something I have to buy. Nothing I haven't seen before. So I ignored it.My character looked about as generic as a Skyrim character by the end of it. And you know what else? It looked worse In-game than it did in the character creation screen. I figured it was my settings. I noticed that it was set to Custom and that everything looked terrible. I did what any smart gamer would do and put it to Ultra. It looked the exact freakin' same. I put it to Custom and maxed out everything slowly, checking for differences in between. No changes that greatly improved the game's look. Wow, so everything looks like a dated 2000's MMO game. Awesome! -_-So my character's head looked well modeled but the body didn't. I could clearly see a low texture just under the neck line as everything there looked like pixels. Burry, crappy, pixels. This was all with everything on Maximum settings. Sure, the hair looked nice and shinny and never changed but my character's arms looked off, either too long or too pixeled. I blamed the textures.I figured, maybe the gameplay is better than it looks since the menu selecting my class type looked very promising. HA! Big fat nothing there. It's basically a mish-mash of talents used to create a supposed new class. I ended up getting two skills that are almost 100% exactly the same. The "build guide" used for the Tanky Tank just placed points into both Tanking trees and gave whatever double ups there were. The talents in general are either meh or interesting but there just so damn many of them. The trees also go in two directions. I hadn't seen split points since Titan Quest and at least there it did it right. Alright, so were the skills at least good? Nope. Basically exactly the same as WoW with possibly better looking icons and Action Bar animations. The XP bar looked great but leveling up was pretty lackluster.So, I played the damn game. I accepted quests and did as they asked. Normal stupid fetch this, or wack that 4 times. None of them were interesting or challenging. I continued, I used my skills like they were intended but I must be too low a level to feel the real greatness of the game because after leveling a few times on the most boring enemies period, It was just tiresome. Enemies that did attack you, didn't pose an actual threat. Enemies you attacked, barely could defend themselves. I stopped attacking to see if one could kill me and it took so long just to get me CLOSE to half health that I killed it. The combat never improved enough to stop me from being bored of it as a whole. My skills weren't interesting to use nor were they fun.The animations looked like a good start but the actual skills were just copy-pastes. The skill effects were as you expected up until the fact that the Tank is basically playing as a Rogue. Instead of Combo Points I have... Attack Points. Like WoW, I get the little icon and improve damage.The areas looked less fantasy like and more generic MMO trying its hardest to be realistic looking. For me, it looked bland, boring and useless. Nothing was unique about it. Nothing I haven't seen a million times in lesser games already.I couldn't get past how worse than WoW it looked and felt. For a WoW clone you'd think they'd get this down.Anyway, I've moaned enough about this game.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Rift did quite well when it launched. It sold 2 million units and held a pay to play model of $15/month, competed well with WoW, kept updating content without releasing new games, and went free to play with microtransactions. I purchased into this games early launch beta and played for the first 3 months of it's launch.Rift is a great MMO, encourages exploration and has many puzzle mini games that are quite fun and refreshing after you have been questing and/or closing rifts. The raiding/group system is much like wow with support roles having a magnified and essential role within the group. There are 20 man raids which consist of 4 groups of 5. The 5 man dungeons in Rift consist of a tank, healer, support which heals and does damage at the same time, and two dps classes. The talent trees are fun and innovative, there are 4 classes (mage, rogue, cleric, warrior) and each has 8 talent trees of which you can have 3 active at a time to build your character and dictate what spells and abilities it will have. You can buy many extra talent specs, I know of at least 5 specs being possible. I play a rogue class and it has 1 tank spec, 1 support/heal spec, and 6 dps specs. There is an aoe spec, stealth assasin spec, ranged marksman spec, ranged hunter with animal pet spec, elemental dps spec, and a pvp spec that has high evasion. I can't speak much for the other classes but I know that the mage has 1 support/heal spec and 7 dps specs, summoner, spellcaster builds, etc. The Cleric has a couple tank specs, many heal specs, and pvp dps tank specs. The warrior has 3 tank specs and 5 dps specs. I don't know much about the other classes but that should be a good enough overview, pardon me if there are discrepenciesThere is an intricate player housing system. You can work towards filling your 'dimension' as they are called with tons and tons of items. Items such as beds, chairs, bookshelves, etc. There are More than 200 from what I have seen. Some are purchased through reputation which you have to grind like WoW, some are bought through the microtransactions store, you can trade for things other players have bought, and you can find things in the open world as well as from Group and Raid rifts.The warfront system is the PvP system in Rift and it is quite fun, there are multiple modes, capture the flag, control points for an amount of time, etc. Much like WoW again. I don't PvP much if at all, it's not what I like about MMOs.This game had a lot going for it and still does, it has aged very well, still has an active community, and will run on most rigs. It was a strong competitor of WoW and still continues to provide content updates and a fresh take on the MMO genre. 10/10 would recommend.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												It's like TBC WoW, and it's free, if you have patience to grind resources, then sell them on chat and a helpful guild to give ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of bonuses you can and will enjoy this game to its fullest, free of charge, I'm full T1-T2 and only paid for Cosmetics (because I really liked some skins) and I regret it everyday since now you can craft cosmetics in the game with certain proffs. The only reason you would pay is if you are really impatient with grinding marks and stuff , money advances you faster, but with the last Tiers of armor in the game , money doesn't help. Good ol' TBC-level raids, with complex and easy bosses . 7 x T1/20man bosses, 4 x T1/10man bosses, 11xT2/20man bosses and 4xT2/10man bosses. The 10man raids also have Hardmodes for extra drops of the same tier or Easy mode if you just want the marks and dont need drops anymore.I've played WoW, Aion and Dragons Prophet before, this game is the best of them for 0 money.Kids who can't grind daily quests because of ADHD will complain that you need to pay for AH permission and Earring Wearing Permission, but in truth in 2 weeks max of grind you are the same as if you've paid 64.99 Euro.

I am sad that I did not get into this game sooner.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												RIFT... its like Wow, but with less paywalls. Its f2p through and through, as far as i can tell, with cosmetics that you can buy with real money. It isn't p2w, I'd say... Love it though, its simple, actiony, and all around fun!Pros-Concise-Great graphics-Good community-Everytime you find a new weapon, it saves its appearance as a skin, which you can put on your other weapons. ie, Steel Longsword could look like a rare tier weapon, but still holds the Steel longswords stats.-Decent classes that aren't super limited to their weapon orientationCons-Easily gets boring-PvP is sometimes a bit unfair in the matchmaking department, but I wont complain.-Armor is kind of plain, which makes it realistic, but cmon...-Story kind of falls through after a whileAll in all, 8/10 game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												After many years of playing World Of Warcraft, for me, RIFT is everything WOW is not. I feel that RIFT is like a better looking younger brother, copying WOW's every move but doing it slightly better. On some forums I would be shot for saying such things but it's true. RIFT is an incredibly immersive experience with a silly amount of stuff to do. Listing the positives would result in a very long review so I'll say this; Play it, level a character and find a decent guild native to your geographial location. It will take you about a year until you start getting bored then you can play around with the custom dimension building after which time a new expansion will be released!My only bad note is that it's free to play with in game purchase options. Personally I'm against this structure but they have kept the good stuff out of reach of fat wallet speed demons!

												I played GW2 first and many ways Rift is like that - lot of dynamic events and tons of things what you can do.Economic seems to be fair enough, you can earn game currency (= value of real money) via playing so if you determined enough, you can unlock everything in time without paying.Story is interesting and levelling really fun and rewarding.This isnt perfect game but very nice mmorpg and one of the best F2P for sure.7/10EDITED:After playing this around 200hrs I saw where its going. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Rift did quite well when it launched. It sold 2 million units and held a pay to play model of $15/month, competed well with WoW, kept updating content without releasing new games, and went free to play with microtransactions. I purchased into this games early launch beta and played for the first 3 months of it's launch.Rift is a great MMO, encourages exploration and has many puzzle mini games that are quite fun and refreshing after you have been questing and/or closing rifts. The raiding/group system is much like wow with support roles having a magnified and essential role within the group. There are 20 man raids which consist of 4 groups of 5. The 5 man dungeons in Rift consist of a tank, healer, support which heals and does damage at the same time, and two dps classes. The talent trees are fun and innovative, there are 4 classes (mage, rogue, cleric, warrior) and each has 8 talent trees of which you can have 3 active at a time to build your character and dictate what spells and abilities it will have. You can buy many extra talent specs, I know of at least 5 specs being possible. I play a rogue class and it has 1 tank spec, 1 support/heal spec, and 6 dps specs. There is an aoe spec, stealth assasin spec, ranged marksman spec, ranged hunter with animal pet spec, elemental dps spec, and a pvp spec that has high evasion. I can't speak much for the other classes but I know that the mage has 1 support/heal spec and 7 dps specs, summoner, spellcaster builds, etc. The Cleric has a couple tank specs, many heal specs, and pvp dps tank specs. The warrior has 3 tank specs and 5 dps specs. I don't know much about the other classes but that should be a good enough overview, pardon me if there are discrepenciesThere is an intricate player housing system. You can work towards filling your 'dimension' as they are called with tons and tons of items. Items such as beds, chairs, bookshelves, etc. There are More than 200 from what I have seen. Some are purchased through reputation which you have to grind like WoW, some are bought through the microtransactions store, you can trade for things other players have bought, and you can find things in the open world as well as from Group and Raid rifts.The warfront system is the PvP system in Rift and it is quite fun, there are multiple modes, capture the flag, control points for an amount of time, etc. Much like WoW again. I don't PvP much if at all, it's not what I like about MMOs.This game had a lot going for it and still does, it has aged very well, still has an active community, and will run on most rigs. It was a strong competitor of WoW and still continues to provide content updates and a fresh take on the MMO genre. 10/10 would recommend.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												Have technically played this game since launch, and have 3 level 50+s.If you are looking for a MMO, I'd definitely give this game a shot, it's pretty old but it has a ton of content for free.With that said, I would never purchase 95% of the things in the store because they are severely overpriced. If you can't see beyond the cash shop (which is pretty much entirely optional outside of primalist and some souls) then don't try this game. If you can see that there is quite a lot of free content available, only barring you from a few souls and one class, all of which are either balanced or weaker than their counterparts, you should definitely try it out. I used to raid in Rift a long time ago, the raiding was actually better than WoW's at the time, I believe it was Post-Ulduar WotLK, which I never found fun (ICC was decent at best). Nowadays the raiding is still pretty great, not quite BC-quality raiding, but it's certainly better than most raiding out right now in any other game.As for the PvP, it's pretty much just like WoW's PvP, what do you expect?Leveling blows, just like in any other MMO, and the story is extremely mediocre, but what MMOs actually do leveling right nowadays? The only one I can think of is FF14.All in all, if you're a raider, then give the game a shot for sure.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												I've played many, many MMOs over the years, and this happens to be one out of the five that I keep coming back to. If you are like many people that I have met and have wanted to bring your friends into a game but find that backtracking or making another character is just sooo boring, or sooo painful to do, this is your game. This is the game that ends that. You wanna know how? Simple.You can delevel yourself without it being permanent, so playing with new player friends, guildies, strangers, or experiencing old content you liked is no longer an issue. Pretty damn sick, right? I've only known Guild Wars 2 to do this, and I really didn't like how it was...forced. But that's because I'm one of those pain-in-the-asses that doesn't like the content to pummel the crap out of me just because I wanted to go and help my buddy on his quest to kill an elite monster.I'm also a sucker for dungeons and PVE content, and they seem to always be improving. Solo content is also pretty rewarding, but please remember this is an MMO, so you're going to have a ton of those "kill some rats and I'll give you some silver, pretty boy" quests. Not sure why people complain about that when they know what kind of game this is in the first place.Do you like roleplaying? If so, they have a dedicated roleplaying server. This is definitely worth looking into seeing as the community isn't all that horrible to each other LIKE SOME GAMES WE KNOW OF. *Cough cough*I also believe the most hardcore selling point of this entire thing is the customization of your class. You get to mix and match three "souls" to change up your abilities and buffs. Purchasing more than one specialization to have more combinations of these specs is done with the in game currency rather than the cash, and few of the other souls are locked by the cash as well. Spending money also is very, very worth it, and this is coming from someone that is very stingy if it's a free to play game. I don't believe in throwing my paycheck at something unless it's a damn good deal, and these guys know how to build their microtransaction shop. Plus, the option of a subscription is even better. Nice buffs to your experience gain and gold gain that you can switch off at any time.If there's anything to hate, it's probably the weird sci-fi fantasy mix of a story they made. I've seen far better. But I'm picky.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												I've played Rift since beta and I have to say teh Gameplay has got since release. Was not a bad game at all but like all games on release there is just so much that can be better and I have to say Trion is pretty good at doing that. People say it's a P2W but that certainly isn't true, on release it used to be SUB only and it went F2P later. Since then you have more problems with the game but that's to be expected. You never HAVE to actually spend any money beyond the inital $5 it takes to make your account a NON FTP account. There are so many rich peopel that buy things in game and you can just pay them in game currecny for ANYTHING you want in the shop. The questing is like most MMO's but I do enjoy the storyline (personal opinion) and there is always something to do. A bit of a grind at end-game but I personally enjoy earning all your gear the hard way it just seems more rewarding. I went from WoW to Rift and nowadays in WoW so much gear is given to you endgame its just no longer a rewarding feeling.  (once again, personal opinion) I feel it's not PTW because you can NEVER buy BiS (Best in slot) gear you have to earn it. You can however buy teh next tier down for example..If the current raids are up to T2 conent then you can only buy T1 in stores with real money until T3 is released. I don't enjoy everything about this game but it is certainly a game that takes up alot of time if you are into raiding, so be prepared and I hope you enjoy it as much as I do :)

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												Have technically played this game since launch, and have 3 level 50+s.If you are looking for a MMO, I'd definitely give this game a shot, it's pretty old but it has a ton of content for free.With that said, I would never purchase 95% of the things in the store because they are severely overpriced. If you can't see beyond the cash shop (which is pretty much entirely optional outside of primalist and some souls) then don't try this game. If you can see that there is quite a lot of free content available, only barring you from a few souls and one class, all of which are either balanced or weaker than their counterparts, you should definitely try it out. I used to raid in Rift a long time ago, the raiding was actually better than WoW's at the time, I believe it was Post-Ulduar WotLK, which I never found fun (ICC was decent at best). Nowadays the raiding is still pretty great, not quite BC-quality raiding, but it's certainly better than most raiding out right now in any other game.As for the PvP, it's pretty much just like WoW's PvP, what do you expect?Leveling blows, just like in any other MMO, and the story is extremely mediocre, but what MMOs actually do leveling right nowadays? The only one I can think of is FF14.All in all, if you're a raider, then give the game a shot for sure.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												I have played this game for over 5 years now, off and on. It is well worth my time and investment. People may say that it is a WoW clone, they can, but it doesn't have all of WoW's poor story writing, terrible voice acting, horrifying bad puns and pop culture references, it has actual story and content that is very challenging and requires attention.I have spent over 1000$ on this game during my time played, does that make it Pay to win? No, Everything can be earned in game with a bit of grinding, but the grinding isn't absurd and you can usually get 2-3 pieces of the set armor your looking for with a bit of hard work and a day or two of play time.The game features have been additional as I have played, they added a card collection which you can use on your cellular devices if you cant login.The developers like to keep the playerbase happy with new content and events every week and frequently post updates or changes to balance and modifications to dungeons, but fixes and reports of issues are encouraged by the playerbase.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Unlike many other mmorpgs available on the market right now...people actually play this. No...I mean they play it like an mmo....as in they play it in groups, raids, events, adventures, dungeons, etc. You could just solo your way to the top, if you wanted, but many people actually group which makes this a whole lot more fun to play. You wont find hackers and dual-boxers galore here...no one needs to hack or dual box because the game is well balanced. Also, you can change roles, no not classes, but roles. Any class can adjust to tank, heal, support, or DPS as needed for any playstyle you desire. This one is worth a sub but its free and not pay to win either. Sure you can get some cosmetic items and buy some exp boosters, but you don't really need all that. Leveling is not a slow boring grind. It's fast...so long as you stay active in all the events. You can quest too, if you want, so much here to do!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												Rift may not be as popular as some a MMO such as World Of Warcraft but in my opinion this game is just as good if not better. Yes it's FTP (free to play) and some may be upset when they find out that some features are locked unless you dish out a little money. Their prices are a little expensive in my opinion but that being said if you save up enough ingame money (platinum) you can buy either from the auction house or from the world chat an item called REX which will allow you to buy said features/items that usually you'd have to pay real money for. So yes you can do virtually everything you'd like in this game for free.I love that they mave made this game so that you can custom build your character however you'd like. In games like World of Warcraft you would only be able to choose 3/4 specs/builds per class but in Rift you can use 3 at once as a cominbation to compliment eachother. And there are multiple combinations per class. For example I recently made a damage over time mage with a few healing spells and a tanky pet. You can make whatever kind of character you'd like. There are also guides for those that aren't sure what to take.Overall I really enjoy this game and definately recommend giving it a go. In my opinion it's currently better then World of Warcraft.

I never got any indication for it.  The only thing that I can think of was at the time, I had a Razer Nostromo gamepad plugged in and it has macro support, yet they don't allow macros.  I wasn't using it though.Fast forward several months, I was unbanned for some reason so I gave the game a try.  Although it's a fun game with a lot of class/skill customization, I've since moved on to other games.TL;DR - Fun game, bad support staff.  Don't leave your Razer Nostromo plugged in.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												So I have this game from closed beta.I redownloaded here for the acheivements but I have 1000s of hours invested in RiftIts a 6 outta 10 MMORPGThe base game is very easy (to easy) and that makes it less then what it should beLike most of the post WOW MMORPGs that went for the easy crowd, Rift has gotten easier and easier over the years trying to appeal to the "casual" gamer. I personally feel this is a mistake (that they all do it) and hurts the game over all.Trion might be coming around to see that as in their big expansion after release the new lands presented more challenge then original lands did (but still very soloable)I have not tried the most recent expansion yet, so can not say if that more challenge continued or not.But Rift is a GOOD MMORPG.Like most F2P games the crafting is all but non existant now because they look to make money from cash store, so everything sold there.The BIGGEST upside for RIFT  over say Star Wars: The Old Republic, is everything for sale in the cash shop is obtainable in game via playing the game. So the cash shop has not replaced game content like in SW:TOR. Its just made it more accessable for those willing to pay extra.Rift housing is spectacular. Easily the strongest aspect of the gameClass system is interesting though greatly watered downbut ultimately RIFTS ar ewhat make Rift and they are fun to chase and destroyAs I said, Rift is a GOOD gameNot a great gameNot a terrible gamejust a good game that is visually appealing over all

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												This game has alot of content and hours of playtime. I like the lvling scheme as well as the items that one can acquire while questing or participating in raids. The early grind can be a bit daunting but once you reach level 50 you can run most areas quickly while farming. Now there is even chests you are given for reaching specific levels such as 10, 20, 30, etc with mounts, weapons, and other goods. I have over 500 hrs altogether logged mostly off the glyph but I log in through Steam now just to change it up. *A Note* any new players to rift if you can grind out 2000 plus plantinum which is in game currency you can purchase REX from the in house auction which is as good as real money for patron pass and other items.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												So, while I realise that I haven't spent all that long playing this game, this is by far my favourite MMO. The Soul system feels unique, and interesting, enabling me to play any role with any character (if you pay for the extra souls).Yes, some features are behind a paywall, but they aren't necessary features. And the ones that are deemed "necessary" can still be bought for in-game currency. I believe that Trion has balanced the pay-wall versus grind really well.I have personally spent quite a lot of money on this, not because I have to, but because I love this game. I recommend it to every MMO-lover I know, as the best free-to-play WoW clone ever made.7/10, the 60-65 grind can be kindof a ♥♥♥♥♥.
